urn:contentItem:5RKK-0H91-F0J6-J0WG-00000-00Hell of Australia Day at Lake Burrumbeet leaves campers cold2018-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEHell of Australia Day at Lake Burrumbeet leaves campers coldVictoria Stone-Meadows

Anti-social behaviour at the Lake Burrumbeet campgrounds over the Australia Day long weekend has turned a number of locals away from the site.

Incidents including hooning, public drunkenness, extreme littering, and a dog attack all occurred in the space of a few days at the lake's campgrounds.

Carly Turner was at the lake for a few minutes on Australia Day when her miniature poodle Ralph was attacked by another dog.

"I had just got out of the car and the ladies next to us said 'our friend's dog is here and it's dangerous. Don't let your dogs near it, it will kill them'," Ms Turner said.

"I'm heading back to the car to get the leads for my dogs when this other lady's dog comes flying forward and it came off its lead and made a b-line for Ralph.

"He he was running away from the dog, but it was was too late and it grabbed him by his back leg and smashed Ralph's head into the ground.

Ms Turner said she thought the dog was an American staffy but claimed the owner told her it was a pitbull and she couldn't make it release Ms Turner's dog.

In trying to save Ralph, Ms Turner was also bitten by the other dog, sustaining two puncture wounds on her thigh.

Ralph suffered a dislocated hip and many lacerations as well as broken tendons and ligament, muscle, and nerve damage; he may still lose his leg if he cannot fully recover.

Ms Turner attempted to report the attack at the Ballarat Police Station but said the police there were not interested in helping her.

Police at Ballarat confirmed to The Courier they were not currently investigating any dog attacks.

"I called the council but they said there was nothing they can do either," she said.

"DELWP fobbed me off as well; they took my details and said they would will it pass on to the council ranger, I have been hand-balled in circles.

"I'm angry that the owner took that dog in a public place knowing it was dangerous, it could have been a child that was attacked, it could have been their face mauled off."

Another camper at Burrumbeet on Australia Day, who wished not to be identified, said they would not camp there again on an event weekend.

The woman and her family were planning to spend the weekend camping but dangerous behaviour and fighting ruined their trip.

"We went to bed at about 10pm and the at about about 2am a car, don't know how fast, flew along the dirt road and then two more cars possibly chasing it.

"There were kids asleep in tents and swags everywhere and I was really worried.

She said she could hear people fighting all night and spent her night worried for her family's safety.

"It was feral, there was a speed boat out on the water at 2am and I thought someone would get killed; I thought it was crazy," she said.

The woman and Ms Turner were left frustrated with the lack of supervision and responsibility authorities provided at the lake.â€‹

"Maybe there needs to be some monitoring or something done, it's a shame it has to come to that," Ms Turner said.

"You would think adults would be responsible enough to have a drink and enjoy camping without all of this."

"I think before they provide supervision, they will just ban camping," the other camper said.

"People need to learn to look after it and leave it as a place people can go and enjoy it."

Who is responsible for managing the Lake Burrumbeet Campgrounds?

Following the damage and refuse left behind at Lake Burrumbeet on Australia Day, The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) and City of Ballarat have both distanced themselves from management responsibilities of the area.

DELWP are officially responsible for the management of Lake Burrumbeet after City of Ballarat handed over management in 2015, except in the case of the caravan park and the racecourse.

City of Ballarat Director of Infrastructure and Environment Terry Demeo said council have no plans to take back over management of the lake campgrounds despite recent events.

"Following extensive negotiations with the Crown, Council resolved to relinquish its committee of management status over Lake Burrumbeet in 2014, and the handover to DELWP was completed in 2015," he said.

"At this stage, Council has no plans to seek the reversal of that decision."

While DELWP are responsible for management of the campgrounds at the lake, Forest Fire Management Victoria Midlands District Manager, Jasmine Filmer said decisions about the area are not made by DELWP alone.

"Management decisions are made in consultation with partners and key stakeholders," she said.

"DELWP manages Lake Burrumbeet in partnership with the City of Ballarat, the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation, Fisheries Victoria and the Glenelg Hopkins CMA."

Ms Filmer said enforecmet of the campground rules are enforced but it is the responsibility of campers in the area to treat each other, the provided facilities, and the land with respect.

"Appropriate use of the lake is guided by legislation and council local laws with officers from DELWP, Victoria Police, Fisheries Victoria, Game Management Authority, and City of Ballarat monitoring the lake area," she said.

"DELWP maintains the toilet facilities, but does not provide bins so campers are expected to take their rubbish home with them."

"DELWP's authorised officers monitor this camp site on a regular basis."â€‹

Lake left trashedâ€‹

Rangers were left astounded by the condition of the Lake Burrumbeet campsite following Australia Day celebrations.

Rangers attended the site on Monday to find alcohol bottles and cans, food packaging, syringes and other waste strewn all over the camping ground.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria crew were tasked with cleaning up the refuse and bagged up all the rubbish before filling seven trailers with dumped trash.

FFM Victoria Midlands District Manager Jasmine Filmer said she was offended by the state the site was left in and the lack of respect shown by those who were there.

"This behaviour not only has a negative effect for fellow holiday-makers but also for those left with the job of cleaning up after an obviously wild weekend," she said.

"It has taken an entire work day for a four-person crew to clean up the rubbish left at the site, which included general waste, bits of old carpet and syringes."

As well as the rubbish, the facilities at the camp site were damaged with crews having to return for repairs.

"We have never seen so much rubbish left behind after a long weekend at any campsite in the Midlands District, despite our repeated efforts to encourage campers to pack up their rubbish and take it home," Ms Filmer said.

"In addition, a Variable Message Sign located at the entry to the park showing important safety messaging for camp users leading into an extremely hot weekend, was deliberately vandalised, a serious criminal offence.

"It is an affront to our crews to have to clean up and fix up after willful and lazy revelers.

"The outcome of such disrespect is that our crew then becomes unavailable for more important forestry and fuel management activities.

"It is visually offensive, can be dangerous to humans and wildlife, and is damaging to the environment."

urn:contentItem:5MNT-Y0J1-F0J6-J36J-00000-00Crops threatened after lightning ignites fire2016-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisCrops threatened after lightning ignites fireSophie Boyd

FIREFIGHTERS have battled the first bushfires of the season, after lightning and heat combined to ignite several fires in the Wimmera.

Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said Forest Fire Management Victoria and Country Fire Authority crews extinguished a single tree fire on the edge of the Grampians National Park and had effectively contained a blaze at Peechember Swamp.

Firefighters also responded to reports of a fire near Big Desert National Park and a possible barley crop fire near Sheep Hills Road at Laen North.

Mr Manning said a single tree was hit by lightning and ignited about 2.30pm on Monday but was quickly contained and extinguished.

He said firefighters would be on scene at Peechember Swamp for several days.

"It's a relatively small fire, about five hectares and it's effectively contained by our crews and Country Fire Authority crews," he said.

"We've bulldozed a containment line around the fire but in the swamp there are lots of river red gums, which will take a considerable amount of time to put out."

Mr Manning said early responders managed to prevent the fire spreading to a wheat crop immediately east of the reserve.

"Country Fire Authority crews on site early dealt with a couple of spot fires in the crop but there was no major impact, which is a good thing," he said.

"There was no risk to any communities."

Mr Manning said a full investigation of the fire had not yet been undertaken but firefighters believed the blaze was caused by a lightning storm on Sunday night.

He said the fires should act as a reminder the fire season had arrived.

"Cooler weather is forecast for next week," he said.

"It's a timely reminder for us all. It's been wet and fairly green but everything's curing now. It's really a reminder to be fully prepared for the summer season ahead. It's right on our doorstep."

Country Fire Authority regional duty officer Neville Collins said residents should not be complacent after the recent rain.

"Take precautions with your property, make sure everything is cleaned up," he said.

"Certainly the fire season is on us now. Lightning will bring fire, so be mindful.

"Everything is starting to dry out so people should not be complacent. Everything is getting ready to burn, even in cooler weather fires burn."

urn:contentItem:5P2W-G741-JD34-V46F-00000-00'Big dry' points to early fire season2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8'Big dry' points to early fire seasonPeter Hannam

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up, heightening concerns the coming fire season will be an early and active one.

Fire authorities won't formally release predictions for spring and summer until September. Wet periods in autumn, though, curbed hazard-reduction burning to half the year-earlier totals in NSW and curtailed it in Victoria. Authorities stress a significant rain event may yet push fire risks for the coming season back towards more typical levels but note there is little sign of such a development.

High-pressure systems have dominated southern Australia, nudging rain-bearing systems south of the continent.

Barring some unexpected instability, July will join last month as among Australia's driest. Nationally, last month was the second-driest June since standard data began in 1910. Rainfall was barely a third of average, the Bureau of Meteorology said.

Victoria had its driest June, NSW was the driest in 15 years and the Murray Darling Basin posted its lowest rainfall totals since 1986.

"It very much seems to be centring on the border between Victoria and NSW," Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre, said of the rainfall deficits.

Winter-to-date rainfall levels have been "very much below average" for most of southern Australia, bureau data shows.

Up until June, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews conducted 351 burns over 113,172 hectares. "The wet winter and spring conditions proved difficult, however our prioritisation of burns based on risk has resulted in the statewide risk being maintained at 2015-16 levels," said Stephanie Rotarangi, the agency's chief fire officer.

The key influence behind this relatively dry winter is far to the south. A positive phase in the so-called Southern Annular Mode marks a polewards contraction of the westerly winds belt towards Antarctica.

As the bureau notes, such a phase marked the "big dry" of 1997 -2010. High-pressure systems that normally sit further north track across more southerly parts of Australia, blocking rain-bearing cold fronts.

In June, average mean sea level pressure readings were at record highs for many parts of southern Australia, including all but one site in South Australia and all but three in Victoria. As the bureau noted: "Mean sea level pressure over southern Australia has been increasing in winter over recent decades. This pattern is consistent with future climate change projections for the Australian region."

Dr Thornton said that, along with trends towards drier winters for southern Australia, warmer-than-average temperatures during July to September were also the new norm.

urn:contentItem:5HT0-91H1-DYG0-92WX-00000-00VIC:Power cut to Vic bushfire-affected towns2016-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Power cut to Vic bushfire-affected townsMELBOURNE Jan 7

  Power has been cut in Wye River and Separation Creek after debris from the Christmas Day bushfires started a pole fire.
   The 2500-hectare Wye River Jamieson Track bushfire destroyed 116 homes in the two small towns and closed the Great Ocean Road for more than 10 days at the height of the holiday season.


   PowerCor spokeswoman Avi Tan said the pole fire, in Wye River, was started by debris kicked up from rain overnight.
   "Given the complexity of the problem we expect power to be out in the area until 3.30pm," Ms Tan told AAP on Thursday.
   Wye River incident control spokesman Angus Mair said most sewerage and water pumps would also likely be stopped while the power was out, because the bulk of them ran off electricity.
   The problem would cause some logistical problems on Thursday, but wouldn't hamper the recovery effort, he said.
   "It's all systems go," he told AAP.
   Residents who are returning to inspect their properties must first register with council and collect a recovery kit, and are then escorted to their home.
   Those whose properties are in a risk area are only allowed inside for one hour, with supervision.
   The Great Ocean Road re-opened fully on Wednesday, offering business owners and tourism operators some relief.
   More than 300 firefighters, including 23 dense forest fire specialists from New Zealand, are battling the fire, which is still burning out of control in thick bush.
   Mr Mair said some of the firefighters on the ground would walk for kilometres, through rough terrain and with huge packs of supplies on their backs, to extinguish hot spots in the bush after they were detected by aerial sensors.
   "It's that inaccessible, that's the only way it can be done," he told AAP.
   Weak winds and cool temperatures have helped firefighters trying to build containment lines around the 2500-hectare Wye River fire, which is burning in dense and mountainous forest.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria crew were tasked with cleaning up the refuse and bagged up all the rubbish before filling seven trailers with dumped trash.

FFM Victoria Midlands District Manager Jasmine Filmer said she was offended by the state the site was left in and the lack of respect shown by those who were there.

"This behaviour not only has a negative effect for fellow holiday-makers but also for those left with the job of cleaning up after an obviously wild weekend," she said.

"It has taken an entire work day for a four-person crew to clean up the rubbish left at the site, which included general waste, bits of old carpet and syringes."

As well as the rubbish, the facilities at the camp site were damaged with crews having to return for repairs.

"We have never seen so much rubbish left behind after a long weekend at any campsite in the Midlands District, despite our repeated efforts to encourage campers to pack up their rubbish and take it home," Ms Filmer said.

"In addition, a Variable Message Sign located at the entry to the park showing important safety messaging for camp users leading into an extremely hot weekend, was deliberately vandalised, a serious criminal offence.

"It is an affront to our crews to have to clean up and fix up after willful and lazy revelers.

"The outcome of such disrespect is that our crew then becomes unavailable for more important forestry and fuel management activities.

"It is visually offensive, can be dangerous to humans and wildlife, and is damaging to the environment."

urn:contentItem:5M73-M961-JD34-V0WY-00000-00Crops threatened after lightning ignites fire2016-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisCrops threatened after lightning ignites fireSophie Boyd

FIREFIGHTERS have battled the first bushfires of the season, after lightning and heat combined to ignite several fires in the Wimmera.

Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said Forest Fire Management Victoria and Country Fire Authority crews extinguished a single tree fire on the edge of the Grampians National Park and had effectively contained a blaze at Peechember Swamp.

Firefighters also responded to reports of a fire near Big Desert National Park and a possible barley crop fire near Sheep Hills Road at Laen North.

Mr Manning said a single tree was hit by lightning and ignited about 2.30pm on Monday but was quickly contained and extinguished.

He said firefighters would be on scene at Peechember Swamp for several days.

"It's a relatively small fire, about five hectares and it's effectively contained by our crews and Country Fire Authority crews," he said.

"We've bulldozed a containment line around the fire but in the swamp there are lots of river red gums, which will take a considerable amount of time to put out."

Mr Manning said early responders managed to prevent the fire spreading to a wheat crop immediately east of the reserve.

"Country Fire Authority crews on site early dealt with a couple of spot fires in the crop but there was no major impact, which is a good thing," he said.

"There was no risk to any communities."

Mr Manning said a full investigation of the fire had not yet been undertaken but firefighters believed the blaze was caused by a lightning storm on Sunday night.

He said the fires should act as a reminder the fire season had arrived.

"Cooler weather is forecast for next week," he said.

"It's a timely reminder for us all. It's been wet and fairly green but everything's curing now. It's really a reminder to be fully prepared for the summer season ahead. It's right on our doorstep."

Country Fire Authority regional duty officer Neville Collins said residents should not be complacent after the recent rain.

"Take precautions with your property, make sure everything is cleaned up," he said.

"Certainly the fire season is on us now. Lightning will bring fire, so be mindful.

"Everything is starting to dry out so people should not be complacent. Everything is getting ready to burn, even in cooler weather fires burn."

urn:contentItem:5RHD-DJD1-JD3N-53CS-00000-00BLISTERING State sizzles as mercury soars way up to 47C2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9BLISTERING State sizzles as mercury soars way up to 47CPATRICK McDONALD MITCH MOTT

SPLASHING, sliding and sipping were among the top ways South Australians tried to beat the state's searing weekend heat, but it wasn't enough to help everyone keep their cool.

More than 50 volunteer firefighters were needed to contain a large forest fire south of Adelaide yesterday as temperatures soared.

The fire began just after 4pm in grassland and a tree plantation at Tooperang, near Goolwa, and was burning out of control before 11 CFS crews attended.

Water bombers and aerial surveillance aircraft provided support from above for the crews as they battled the fire in temperatures in the mid-30Cs.

SA Health said that nine people presented to emergency departments across the state yesterday with heat-related illness, three of who were admitted for further treatment.

This was down from another 16 people who sought treatment on Saturday, out of which six were admitted to hospital.

Temperatures reached 47C at Maree in the state's north at 4.07pm, with 46.6C recorded at Oodnadatta, 46.1 in Coober Pedy and Woomera and 46C at Moomba.

In Adelaide, it reached a sweltering 44.1C at Kent Town at 1.21pm, although the West Terrace reading peaked at 41.8C at 11.53am.

Cloud cover was expected to keep last night's minimum to a fairly high 23C, before a cool change with showers and a maximum of 28C forecast for today and fine weather in the mid-to-high 20s for the rest of the working week.

While some of the events at this year's Crush Festival at Adelaide Hills wineries were cancelled because of the extreme weather, those which went ahead still found plenty of patrons in search of a refreshing drink and shady vista.

Water activities remained a popular way to beat the heat.

At Moana Beach, Rachel Glendinning was celebrating her birthday with her daughter Scarlett, 2, and friends Jade and Adam Hicks, with their one-year-old daughter Sierra and son Brayden, 5.

In the northern suburbs, those with the energy to dance got to cool off with a dip between tracks with a DJ at Waterworld Aquatic Centre.

Waterslides and an inflatable obstacle course added to the activities for a big turnout at the Marion Outdoor Pool open day, where Sally Haynes and her sons Chaen, 8, and Jack, 12, joined the fun.

Although The Piece Project street art and music event at Longview Vineyard in Macclesfield was postponed due to the extreme weather, its star attraction, British DJ Norman Jay, instead played a Sunset Session last night for a sellout dance crowd on the River Torrens pontoon in Elder Park.

urn:contentItem:5HT6-87W1-JC0X-K20D-00000-00VIC:Power restored Vic bushfire-affected towns2016-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Power restored Vic bushfire-affected townsCaitlin Guilfoyle and Melissa MeehanMELBOURNE Jan 7

  Power has been restored in Wye River and Separation Creek as an out-of-control bushfire burns deep in Victoria's Otway Ranges.
   Power was cut in the area on Thursday morning after debris from the Christmas Day fires started a pole fire.


   The 2500-hectare Wye River-Jamieson Track bushfire destroyed 116 homes in the two small towns and closed the Great Ocean Road for more than 10 days at the height of the holiday season.
   Powercor spokeswoman Avi Tan said the pole fire, in Wye River, was started by debris kicked up from rain overnight.
   Wye River incident control spokesman Angus Mair said more than 300 firefighters, including 23 dense forest fire specialists from New Zealand, are battling the fire, which is burning in thick bush.
   Mr Mair said some firefighters on the ground would walk for kilometres with heavy supply packs through rough terrain to extinguish hot spots in the bush after they were detected by aerial sensors.
   "It's that inaccessible, that's the only way it can be done," he told AAP.
   On Thursday crews were focusing on cutting down and extinguishing burning hollow trees ahead of the fire front, he said.
   The Great Ocean Road re-opened fully on Wednesday, offering business owners and tourism operators some relief.
   Residents who are returning to inspect their properties must first register with council and collect a recovery kit, and are then escorted to their home.
   Those whose properties are in a risk area are only allowed inside for one hour, with supervision.
   Temperatures on Sunday and Monday are expected to reach 27C, pushing the fire danger rating to high, but with high humidity and low winds, the fire will remain manageable, Mr Mair said.
   Crews expect to get the fire under control by the end of January.

urn:contentItem:5M5T-T5B1-JD34-V0XF-00000-00Higher risk of fire this summer2016-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSHigher risk of fire this summerNatalie Croxon

ABOVE average temperatures and strong vegetation growth are likely to bring a greater risk of fire to much of central Victoria this summer.

The current seasonal bushfire outlook from the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre suggests most of the region, except a small strip in the north, can expect an above normal risk of fire.

Dr David Jones, climate monitoring and prediction manager at the Bureau of Meteorology, said the seasonal climate forecast to January indicated daytime temperatures in the first months of summer would be higher than average for much of central and northern Victoria.

Dr Jones said this, along with a wet winter that had led to significant vegetation growth, would contribute to the higher fire risk.

"Once that vegetation dries out in summer, which it almost certainly will, it raises the risk of fire, particularly grass fire," he said.

CFA District 2 acting operations manager Trent McKinnon said vegetation would dry out "very quickly" with warm, dry and windy weather.

Mr McKinnon said grass fires would be more likely earlier on in the season, but as the forests dried out there would also be a "fairly significant forest fire risk" late January and into February.

The three-month climate outlook suggests central Victoria will experience average rainfall in the warmer months.

Dr Jones said this meant about 20 to 40 millimetres a month across northern and central Victoria.

He said evaporation in the summer months occurred at a rate five to 10 times higher than the amount of precipitation, meaning rain events would have little impact on the fire risk.

While there had been significant rainfall over the past few months, Dr Jones said Victoria had experienced a drier than average season for most of the past 20 years.

Mr McKinnon said the CFA was monitoring environmental conditions and would declare the fire danger period for District 2, which encompassed Bendigo, when it deemed it necessary.

He estimated this would be early to mid-December.

But some parts of the region have already been declared, including Buloke and Gannawarra shires.

Mr McKinnon urged people to begin their fire preparation activities, including removing fuel from around properties, clearing gutters and ensuring a bushfire plan was in place, before the fire danger period began.

urn:contentItem:5V3Y-3FH1-F0J6-J44F-00000-00Inside the fire centre2019-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Inside the fire centreWilliam Vallely

"It doesn't take much to start a fire," seasoned Incident Controller Les Vearing said as he prepared for another day at the helm of the Incident Control Centre.

During days where severe and extreme fire danger ratings are in place, Incident Control Centres are established.

Today, one has been set up at the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning offices in Epsom.

With the mercury set to rise to 45 degrees, the heat, in combination with dry, windy conditions, is a recipe for fires to start, and develop quickly, Mr Vearing said.

"If we get a bad fire going today, once it gets established we won't be able to put it out, we'll have to wait for better conditions," he said.

"The reality is you can have all the resources in the world but under those conditions we're not going to be able to put it out."

That said, hundreds of staff and volunteers across a range of organisations, from the CFA to DELWP, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Victoria Police and the State Emergency Service, will all be on deck.

Some will be at the Incident Control Centre while others will be scattered across the district, which covers large expanses of central and northern Victoria, from Kyneton in the south to Lake Boga in the North and St Arnaud in the west.

Aside from the densely populated areas, like on the Murray River in Echuca, there were no particular areas the incident Control Centre was focused on, Mr Vearing said.

He said the various agencies combined their respective skills sets on the day to provide a broad spectrum of emergency management to protect the community.

Victoria Police for example would organise road blocks, while Ambulance Victoria treats those affected by the heat.

FFMV, the firefighting arm of DELWP, would assist various CFA volunteer crews on the ground, some of which will be waiting at the fire station on extreme fire danger days, rather than having to travel in from work.

Bulldozers and graders remain on standby to cut the fire path of either grass or bushfires, Mr Vearing said.

As do the City of Greater Bendigo, which can provide a range of services for people who might be displaced during a fire.

Two years without major fires in the region could make people become complacent, Mr Vearing said.

"Last year was quiet, this year has been relatively quiet so far but you never know when they're going to come," he said.

"The last significant event was Black Saturday ten years ago but we do get a lot of medium-sized fires in the area we cover."

Despite the lack of recent fire activity, general awareness of fires, how they can start, and how to prepare for them, had improved, he said.

"People are becoming more aware of it and hopefully less inclined to do high-risk activities," he said.

Those activities include cutting grass and open air angle grinding or welding.

Mr Vearing reiterated the prominent fire safety message to the community.

"People need to be actively reviewing their fire plans and implement them and if their plan is to not stay and defend their property then they need to leave early," he said.

"You don't want to be trying to evacuate as the fire is coming towards you.

"Now is too late to start doing those last minute preparations - whipper snipping - it's too late - all you're going to be doing is starting a bushfire."

The Department of Health and Human Services has issued heat health alerts for the Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country, North Central and North East district with most of Victoria set for temperatures of more than 40 degrees.

Dehydration, lack of airflow, sun exposure and hot and crowded conditions can cause heat stress or heat related illness.

Symptoms include deterioration in existing medical conditions, heat rash, heat cramps, dizziness and fainting, heat exhaustion and heatstroke.

urn:contentItem:5K2F-KH11-JD3N-5527-00000-00GLOBAL SNAPSHOT2016-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19GLOBAL SNAPSHOT

Assange request LONDON: Ecuador has received a formal request from Swedish authorities to interview WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange inside its London embassy in a possible breakthrough to the long-running saga.

Bid to cross ocean NEW YORK: The Solar Impulse 2 aircraft yesterday soared over the western Atlantic, one of the most difficult legs of its record-breaking bid to fly across the globe using only solar energy. The plane is piloted by Swiss adventurer Bertrand Piccard, who is expected to spend about 90 hours crossing the Atlantic.

Haitians at risk PORT-AU-PRINCE: More than 130,000 people of Haitian origin living in the Dominican Republic risk deportation because it is nearly impossible for them to renew their temporary residency permits, a migrant aid group official said. Haiti is the poorest country in the Americas.

Yellow fever strikes KINSHASA: The Democratic Republic of Congo has declared a yellow fever epidemic in three provinces, including the capital Kinshasa, after confirming 67 cases of the disease, with another 1000 suspected cases being monitored.

Tumours hit brainy LONDON: Highly educated people are more likely to suffer from brain tumours than those who do not progress as far in their education, a study suggests. Gliomas, the most common type of brain tumour, are more common among people who are university-educated, researchers said.

Firefighter killed NICOSIA: A firefighter died yesterday after being crushed when his truck overturned as he tackled a large forest fire that is raging out of control on the Mediterranean island of Cyprus.

Sect leader bailed PINE CITY: A US judge has set bail at $A2 million for a religious sect leader charged with sexually abusing girls at a secluded compound in rural Minnesota. Victor Barnard, 54, made his first state court appearance since his extradition from Brazil.

Teachers protestOAXACA: Thousands of teachers opposed to an education reform protested in southern Mexico yesterday to denounce the deaths of eight people after weekend clashes that police blamed on armed "radicals". Police said they were investigating whether officers fired first or hit any victims in the clashes in the state of Oaxaca.

Mr Vearing reiterated the prominent fire safety message to the community.

"People need to be actively reviewing their fire plans and implement them and if their plan is to not stay and defend their property then they need to leave early," he said.

"You don't want to be trying to evacuate as the fire is coming towards you.

"Now is too late to start doing those last minute preparations - whipper snipping - it's too late - all you're going to be doing is starting a bushfire."

The Department of Health and Human Services has issued heat health alerts for the Mallee, Wimmera, Northern Country, North Central and North East district with most of Victoria set for temperatures of more than 40 degrees.

Dehydration, lack of airflow, sun exposure and hot and crowded conditions can cause heat stress or heat related illness.

Symptoms include deterioration in existing medical conditions, heat rash, heat cramps, dizziness and fainting, heat exhaustion and heatstroke.

urn:contentItem:5VWX-BPH1-JD34-V3P7-00000-00Community kept at heart2019-04-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Community kept at heart

The passing of John Malone on March 31, is a significant loss to not only his family, but Bundaleer, Jamestown and the wider community.

John's contribution to the community through many organisations was always diligent, reliable, strategic and enthusiastic. He was especially gifted at making people new to the area welcome, whether it be new employees in the Bundaleer Forest in the years prior to 1995, or more recently visitors to Bundaleer recreation grounds or the Jamestown Visitor Resource Centre, which he frequently manned.

His extensive involvement in agricultural spans five decades, taking on leadership positions, stewardship and judging at local, regional and state level. He was Jamestown Show president in 1977, 1978 and 1986, Patron from 2003-2008, and member of the Cattle Committee until his passing. He was granted Honorary Life Membership in 1997.

He also served as President of the Northern Agricultural Shows Association from 1984-86 and was chairman of the Agricultural Societies Council from 1993 to 1996. As a breeder and exhibitor of Red Poll Cattle, John left his mark at the Royal Adelaide Show, Sydney Easter Show, Wodonga Show and Sale, and countless country shows.

But for John, these successes were far outweighed by friendships he made, such was his love of life and people. He hosted many visitors to his Maleer Red Poll Stud, including international visitors on Australian Cattle Industry tours. He took on presidency of both federal and state councils of the Red Poll Society and devoted more than 45 years at committee level, recently acknowledged with life membership. John had extensive involvement in farm industry organisations, serving on numerous State and regional committees of the South Australian Farmers Federation, and its predecessor, United Farmers & Graziers.

He was a member of the body that set up the Jamestown Truck Wash Facility and was also part of a lobby group which successfully retained Jamestown Hospital's acute services in the 1980s. John was also involved in the organics industry, after he and his son Chris achieved certification as organic and biodynamic farmers in 1991.

Sport was an important part of John's life. He played football, tennis, golf and table tennis and in more recent years played bowls. John was involved with the Bundaleer Sport and Recreation Association from its formation as the Bundaleer Progress Association in 1962. He helped with the volunteer cropping program which funded the establishment of tennis courts, a cricket oval and the Bundaleer Hall adjacent the Bundaleer Picnic Ground. In the last 15 years, John and Veronica have been the contact for hundreds of visitors who have camped at the grounds and hired the facilities at Bundaleer.

John was also actively involved in the St James Catholic Church and was a supporter of greater interaction between the churches, as a member of the interdenominational group. John loved classical music and was extremely proud of his daughter Mary Jane's great talent for singing and was a regular at her gigs. He was a major contributor to planning and managing all seven music and art festivals held in the Bundaleer Forest between 1999 and 2013 and he chaired the 2011 event. The final Bundaleer Festival was held just months after the devastating forest fire. John was a key part of the campaign to replant the forest, save the local timber industry and ensure Australia's first plantation forest remained accessible by locals and visitors.

John was proud to be part of the community's efforts to secure ownership and control of the sport and recreation grounds and co-management of the Bundaleer Forest Picnic Ground. He had a great sense of humour and zest for life, loved steak, red wine and barbecues at Bundaleer. He was a highly social being and made enduring friendships through every facet of his life, whether at school, in cattle industry and show meetings, welcoming visitors to Bundaleer, or just stopping for a chat when shifting the cattle along the road with his beloved dog. He adored his community, his cattle, all things Bundaleer, and most of all, his family. John was diagnosed with cancer two years ago and he endured the rigorous treatment regime with his usual optimistic approach to life. With the loving care of Veronica and family he was able to stay at home until just days before his passing.

urn:contentItem:4F20-TGS0-015H-9431-00000-00<published>2004-12-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:40:19Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 19</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest 'fire' flares anew</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>WAYNE CRAWFORD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">EVEN though the Gunns lawsuit will probably do more harm than good for the forest industry, this escalation of the long-running Battle for the Trees was almost inevitable.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Indeed, the environmental movement guaranteed the tit for tat exacerbation of the conflict when it took the big union, the CFMEU, to court over a clash between conservationists and contractors in a Victorian forest nearly six years ago.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Timber workers saw intense irony in claims this week by conservationists that the legal action taken by Gunns was an abuse of power and a challenge to the right of free speech, for it was the environmentalists who cast the first stone in this courtroom clash of titans.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The timber workers' union, the huge Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union, says it was the green movement backed by the Wilderness Society which let the dogs of law off the leash by suing unionists and logging contractors over a picket line they set up in response to an anti-logging protest by conservationists in the Otways rainforest, west of Melbourne, in January 1999. That legal battle has already cost the union nearly $1.5 million in defence costs and the matter is not yet completed: it is still the subject of an appeal by the conservationists and Wilderness Society.</p><p>The blitzkrieg this week by Gunns Limited, Australia's biggest forestry company and the state's biggest private company, will serve only to escalate the horrida bella -- encouraging both sides to dig in even further and making the prospect of compromise in the forests even more remote.</p><p>Australian Greens leader and Tasmanian Senator Bob Brown -- one of 20 conservationists and forest protesters being sued by Gunns for $6.3 million for damaging its business and its reputation -- said on Wednesday after the Franklin Square protest in Hobart against the lawsuits: "They can take every penny, they can take every peaceful night's sleep, they can take every home comfort [but] they will never stop me campaigning against their vile destruction of Tasmanian forests and its wildlife. Not ever. They misjudge we defenders of the forests."</p><p>CFMEU national assistant secretary Michael O'Connor said: "Our members are sick and tired of the outrageous antics of the Green protesters which have resulted in working people in the forests not being able to earn a living, sometimes for months on end. We have had enough of it."</p><p>Both sides are trying to assume the moral high ground. The Greens and Wilderness Society repeatedly claim public opinion is on their side and that as much as 85 per cent of Australians want logging ended in old-growth native forests.</p><p>However, Gunns chief John Gay said this week, in justifying the decision to sue forest protesters: "Gunns Limited and the majority of Tasmanians are sick and tired of the misleading information being peddled about our industry and our state."</p><p>The writs against the 20 individuals and groups involved in forest protests and campaigns against logging are an expression of the company's frustration at what it says has been years of disruption of its activities, the resulting financial loss and vilification of its standing and reputation. The writs cite a range of events and activities, from assault of an employee to sabotage of machinery and interference and disruption of company activities.</p><p>Experienced legal sources have expressed surprise the company would try to demonstrate it has been badly damaged by the forest protests, given that only four months ago it boasted a huge record profit of $105 million for the year, a 42 per cent increase on last year, and that this week its shares have been trading at an all-time high.</p><p>The State Government is staying well out of the legal fracas. It does not want to provide oxygen to the polemic pleadings of the Greens; to jeopardise plans or public support for a billion dollar pulp mill; or to compromise the sensitive negotiations with the Federal Government on a 170,000 hectare, $50 million expansion of state forest conservation reserves.</p><p>The Greens and their supporters say Gunns' legal action is nothing more than "SLAPP writs" -- an acronym for Strategic Litigation Against Public Participation -- aimed purely at depriving ordinary citizens of their right of free speech by intimidating them with legal action that will occupy a great deal of their time and attention and cost them a lot in legal and court expenses, whether or not the lawsuits are successful.</p><p>The CFMEU's Michael O'Connor -- who has been charged with disloyalty to the ALP for his stand against Mark Latham's controversial election promise to lock up 240,000ha of Tasmanian old-growth forest, preventing it from being logged -- says the environmentalists have brought the trouble on themselves.</p><p>When a group of conservationists disrupted logging in Victoria's Otway Range in 1999, the CFMEU responded by setting up a picket line across the only access road to the rainforest. The conservationists, backed by the Wilderness Society, subsequently sued 15 individual timber workers and a CFMEU official in the Victorian Supreme Court, alleging the protesters had been held hostage for five days, "imprisoned" behind the picket line. There were claims the protesters had been threatened, floodlights were trained on them at night and 44-gallon drums were banged to keep them awake.</p><p>The loggers then lodged counter-claims, suing the protesters for loss of income caused by the "direct action" of the environmentalists.</p><p>After years of delays, and evidence from 43 witnesses during a 64-day hearing, Judge David Ashley rejected the allegations of wrongful imprisonment and dismissed about 90 per cent of the hundreds of claims filed by the protesters. He did accept, though, that five protesters had suffered mental distress and awarded them more than $133,000 damages. The environmentalists are appealing the decision.</p><p>The Wilderness Society, meanwhile, quietly settled out of court on the counter suit and paid $45,000 to the contractors, effectively accepting that the protest action had caused them loss of income.</p><p>When the Gunns writs were issued this week, Bob Brown -- one of the "Gunns 20" as they are calling themselves -- said he would not be cowed by the company's "power of destruction" and accused Gunns of trying to "hector" the environmental movement into silence and submission while the "chainsaws and poison" destroy the forests and their wildlife.</p><p>Michael O'Connor, who heads the national forest workers section of the CFMEU, says the union backs Gunns' legal move. He says it is aimed at "protecting the security of our members and the future of our members' families and the survival of timber communities and safety of the workers in the industry", which he claims is jeopardised by the forest protests.</p><p>He says nobody had even considered Supreme Court action over the forest protests until the environmentalists initiated it against forest workers. "They have sown the wind and now they will reap the whirlwind," he said.</p><p>"I think it's ironic that Bob Brown encouraged the action against ordinary working people in the timber industry by Green activists -- and had no sympathy for the workers being sued -- and is now bleating because somebody else in the industry has decided to take action against him in the same Supreme Court. I don't think he's got much to complain about."</p><p>Still, the Greens are past masters at appealing to public sentiment and will milk every last drop of sympathy and emotion from the issue, which will have the effect of drawing the movement's support base closer together.</p><p>The Franklin River, the Wesley Vale pulp mill -- and now the bully from the big end of town trying to sue into submission those who assert their only motivation is to protect the heritage of the nation.</p><p>With the "ordinary working folk" on one side and the altruistic "defenders of the forests" on the other, John Gay has ignited a new shemozzle which will help keep the issue burning <email normalizedValue="mailto:indefinitely.waynecrawford@msn.com.au">indefinitely.waynecrawford@msn.com.au</email></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PTJ-41X1-JD34-V071-00000-00Back to the bush after fires2017-10-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisBack to the bush after fires

A koala and her joey who were rescued from bushfires by Forestry Corporation of NSW firefighters in Mt Boss State Forest late last month were released back into the same forest yesterday after the fires were controlled and the area was assessed as safe.

The koalas were cared for at the Port Macquarie Koala Hospital while the fire threat passed. The hospital named the mother Mt Boss Matilda and her joey Banjo.

Forest Protection Coordinator Shane Dickinson, who found Mt Boss Matilda and Banjo in the path of the fire, smoke affected and dazed, said it was a relief the koalas had made a full recovery and could be safely returned to the forest.

"Fire season has started early this year and we've had all hands on deck fighting fires up and down the coast for several weeks. When I spotted this mother and joey in the path of a fire I immediately called the Port Macquarie Koala Hospital to get their advice and make sure we could get them out of danger," Mr Dickinson said.

"It was great to be able to see the koala and joey in such good health today after the shock of the recent fires and I was pleased to be given the opportunity to return them to the same place I found them, now that the fire danger has passed."

Forestry Corporation Senior Ecologist Chris Slade thanked the Port Macquarie Koala Hospital for caring for the koalas while the fires were brought under control.

"The Port Macquarie Koala Hospital are the experts in caring for fire or smoke-affected koalas so we were grateful to be able to call on them to get Mt Boss Matilda and Banjo to safety," Mr Slade said.

"Now that the forest is safe and the koalas have been given a clean bill of health, we're thrilled to be able to release them back into the forest where they were found.

While the cause of the Mt Boss fire is unclear, there are now 120 hidden infra-red equipped cameras in State forests around Wauchope, Taree, the Hunter, Coffs and Casino areas to catch arsonists, following a spate of suspicious fires and ranger patrols have been ramped up in all State forests.

urn:contentItem:5RCT-N3K1-F0JP-W53S-00000-00Tassie warmer and drier2018-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 28Tassie warmer and drierKAROLIN MACGREGOR

Above average temperatures and below average rainfall were the key features of Tasmania's weather in 2017 according to the Bureau of Meteorology's annual climate review.

Tasmania experienced one of its top 10 warmest years, while across the country 2017 was the third warmest year on record.

Temperatures nationally were .95C higher than the 1961-1990 average. The Bureau's head of climate monitoring, Dr Karl Braganza, said that despite the fact there was no El Nino last year, 2017 was still characterised by very warm temperatures.

"Both day and night-time temperatures were warmer than average, particularly maximum temperatures, which were the second-warmest on record," he said.

"Seven of Australia's 10 warmest years have occurred since 2005 and Australia has experienced just one cooler than average year - 2011 - in the past decade." Oceans around Australia also recorded temperatures well above average and prolonged high sea surface temperatures were associated with significant coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef during early 2017.

Despite the heat, there were also some very cool nights in southern Australia in June and July, associated with long strings of cloudless days.

Dr Braganza said overall it was a mixed year for rainfall.

"The middle of the year was notably dry, with June the second-driest on record nationally, and September the driest on record for the Murray-Darling Basin," he said.

"The last three months of 2017 took a wetter turn, with above-average rainfall in many areas." Averaged over the whole of Australia, rainfall for 2017 was 8 per cent above the 1961-1990 average of 465.2mm.

Annual rainfall was above average for most of central, eastern and northern Western Australia, the west of South Australia, and most of the Northern Territory.

However rainfall totals were below average for most of inland Queensland, most of New South Wales, eastern to central Victoria, and all of Tasmania.

Notably, rainfall was below average across southern Australia during the cooler months of May to September.

A climate change signal has been identified in the reduction of cool season rainfall in southern Australia. There there have been significant declines in rainfall during this period since the 1970s in southwest Western Australia, and since the mid-1990s in southeastern Australia Last year also saw a neutral El Nino - Southern Oscillation for most of the year, but the tropical Pacific Ocean cooled steadily from midwinter and La Nina was declared at the start of December A positive southern annual mode and strong subtropical ridge during winter brought clear skies, frosty nights, and below average winter rainfall.

Record high May to September forest fire danger index values over Queensland and northern New South Wales was a result of prolonged warm and dry conditions It was a very warm November, after a frosty start, due to a long-lived blocking high pressure system over the Tasman Sea, which set records in Victoria and Tasmania Brisbane had a particularly warm year, with the annual mean temperature equal to the warmest on record.Annual mean maximum temperatures were among the top three warmest for the cities of Sydney, Hobart and Canberra.

urn:contentItem:4KNB-6CT0-TX53-B2JG-00000-00IN BRIEF2006-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 18IN BRIEF

Implants save Israeli's life

JERUSALEM, Tuesday -- An Israeli woman's breast implants saved her life when she was wounded in a Hizbollah rocket attack during Israel's war with the Lebanese group, a hospital spokesman said today. Doctors found shrapnel embedded in the silicone implants, just centimetres from the 24-year-old's heart.

Maori queen dies, aged 75

AUCKLAND, Tuesday -- New Zealand's Maori queen has died at the age of 75, after a 40-year reign. Dame Te Atairangikaahu passed away after a long battle with failing health. Dame Te Ata suffered from diabetes and underwent dialysis daily.

Dead baby in locker

SINGAPORE, Tuesday -- A dead baby with its umbilical cord still attached has been found in a staff locker at a Singapore supermarket. Workers noticed a foul smell and used a spare key to open up the locker, where they found the baby in a semi-decomposed condition on Monday. Indications were that the baby had been dead for at least two to three days.

Bomb kills nine in Mosul

MOSUL, Iraq, Tuesday -- A suicide bomber detonated a truck rigged with explosives outside the offices of a top Kurdish political party in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul today, killing nine people and wounding 36, police said. Five Kurdish peshmerga militiamen were among the dead, police said.

Forest fire in France

SAINT TROPEZ, France, Monday -- A large forest fire broke out near the jet-setter's summer resort of Saint Tropez today, reaching several millionaires' villas and causing the evacuation of some 3000 people, French authorities said. The seat of the blaze was at Ramatuelle, just 5km from the chic French Riviera seaside town.

urn:contentItem:5MXP-BWS1-F0JP-W2BD-00000-00Alarm over fire services2017-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Alarm over fire servicesBy PETER HUNT

VOLUNTEER firefighters fear the Victorian Government is preparing to adopt the NSW fire services model, recruiting- "retained" firefighters to cover an extended metropolitan Melbourne boundary and all major regional- cities.

After the United Firefighters Union last week won a major pay deal, volunteers claimed the union had convinced the Government to go a step further and extend the reach of paid career firefighters.

A senior volunteer source said the Government was investigating the NSW model of employing- retained firefighters, who receive $66 a fortnight to be on call and an hourly rate of $32.

The Weekly Times asked Emergency Services Minister and Deputy Premier James Merlino whether the Government was considering a restructure- of the CFA, extending the metropolitan fire boundary and/or adopting the NSW retained firefighters.

Mr Merlino responded by stating: "The Government's focus is on the bushfire season and ensuring our firefighters have the resources to do what they do best - keep Victorians safe".

Opposition Emergency Services spokesman Brad Battin said Premier Daniel Andrews- "needed to make a commitment to CFA volunteers and all Victorian communities the he would not tear apart the CFA".

"This government needs to stop handing control to Peter Marshall and ensure they listen- to volunteer communities' views," Mr Battin said.

The UFU has spent most of the past decade arguing for a restructure of the fire services that would extend its reach and membership. In 2015 the UFU called on the Government to split the fire services into three divisions: CITY Fire - to manage fire and fire risk in cities and towns. FOREST Fire - to manage fuel and fire on public land and plantations. RURAL Fire - to manage, through volunteers, fires in rural areas, including small towns, villages and hamlets.

Victorian UFU boss Peter Marshall did not respond- to The Weekly Times' calls for comment.

Volunteers warn any restructure- would strip the CFA of its surge capacity during major fires and potentially drive up the cost of the Fire Services Property Levy.

"We rely on surge capacity from outer metropolitan areas," Kilmore CFA Captain Dave Williams said.

"If you take out Bendigo, Ballarat, Shepparton and other cities, you'll also lose the volunteers." "I don't think the community can afford it." Mr Williams said volunteers would reject the retained firefighters model. "Volunteers in Victoria have rejected the NSW model before," he said."We're volunteers, so we don't get paid."

urn:contentItem:5VSP-M6W1-JD34-V30C-00000-00Investigation ongoing2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Investigation ongoingGreg Gliddon

THE source of a grass fire which destroyed properties and left a number of people in hospital near Bunkers Hill remains under active investigation.

Initial reports on Friday afternoon were that trees falling onto powerlines could have sparked the blaze which took hold just before 2pm as north-westerly winds picked up ahead of a cool change.

But weekend investigations are understood to have uncovered a number of issues which are now being investigated to determine the cause. Locals have told The Courier they understood the fire may have started along Sago Hill Road.

Ballarat CIU and the CFA are still working to pinpoint the fire's cause, and have so far been unable to rule out whether it was deliberately lit.

The Bunkers Hill fire crossed 134 hectares of land heading in a south-easterly direction towards Smythes Creek before being brought under control before the wind change pushed it towards Ballarat.

A number of houses and sheds were lost in the blaze.

Three people were taken to hospital as a result of the Bunkers Hill fire due to smoke inhalation, while three firefighters required assistance from paramedics, two for smoke inhalation and one with a 'severely lacerated hand'.

Evan Dower, who lives close to where the blaze began, in Greenhalghs Road, said in almost 20 years living in the area, he had never seen a fire like it.

"We were working in the shed and the power went out, it was only me and my eldest son Luke who were around," Mr Dower said.

"By the time we got back to the house, it was coming down at us.

"Luke looked after the animals and rang the fire brigade and I tried to fire an arc around the house. We lost some sheds and machinery, I had to go to hospital with smoke inhalation."

Mr Dower said he initially heard that a tree had fallen onto a powerline.

"I've never felt wind like it," he said. "It was like being in a war zone, trees were falling and crashing all over the place.

"I've lived here almost 20 years and I've never had to use the fire pump before, fortunately I was able to get it going, only thing that saved the house. The firey's, police, volunteers were absolutely unbelievable, the firey's were here all night

"We lost two sheds, some quad bikes, motorbikes, splitters and lots of fences, probably about $30,000 but it could have been a lot worse."

CFA Region 15 operations manager Gavin Hope said, in all, four blazes took hold on Friday afternoon, which saw emergency warnings issued west of Learmonth and Mount Mercer while another blaze was detected at Mount Wallace.

"The Learmonth blaze we believe was a result of a previous burn off, which was of no fault of the farmer and although Geelong is handling the Mount Mercer blaze, we believe it was something similar," he said.

"We also had a small fire out at Mount Wallace, which was actually in the process in the being controlled and it jumped out of containment lines.

"The Bunkers Hill blaze is still under investigation. We had an aircraft go up on Saturday to have a look at where it burned."

Mr Hope described the cooperation of all fires crews on the day as "magnificent."

"It was a mighty effort to stop it in its tracks, it moved very quickly," he said "In all we had four incidents in the area and it did put a strain on our resources, but we managed to get enough trucks.

"While the aircraft had been scaled back, we managed to get a helicopter just in time. The timing was impeccable. It was very sad to lose what we host, but there are a number of houses down there and without that help, it could have been much much worse.

"It was an incredible wind, it was as though a mini-tornado blew through, dangerous fire conditions are around 41km/h, we were over 100km/h."

He also singled out for praise the efforts of crews from Bacchus Marsh and Maryborough and Forest Fire Management Victoria who continued to work over the weekend, particularly in the identification of dangerous trees."

The Bureau of Meteorology said while there were no tornadoes recorded in the area, winds did gust as much as 85km/h around 2pm.

And people are being warned that another similar day can be expected on Friday with temperatures expected to reach the mid 20s and winds picking up again, however the next change is not expected until Saturday morning.

urn:contentItem:5MXX-Y581-JD34-V3BY-00000-00Museum works2017-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisPEOPLE AND PLACESPg. 14Museum works

The second stage of developments at Naracoorte's SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum started last week ahead of an upcoming memorial service.

Staff from Kerkhof Concrete have been hard at work laying the foundations and cementing a small wall at the museum site on Kingston Ave.

Rex Hall, chair of the SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum, said the new wall will be used as a barrier for a garden and car park in preparation for the museum.

A working bee is scheduled for the beautification of the site before a a memorial service is held there soon.

The service on April 22 will focus on the contribution of Forestry SA workers who have lost their lives.

"It's a great sadness when we lose a fire fighter so it is important we pause to reflect on their sacrifice and never forget the bravery they displayed," Mr Hall said.

At the ceremony, a plaque will be unveiled in memory of the eight fire fighters whose lives were taken in the Wandilo forest fire in 1958.

Forestry SA chief executive Jerome Coleman said the plaque was a poignant reminder of the men who died in the course of their fire fighting duties.

"Almost 60 years on, this tragedy remains in the forefront of the minds of local fire fighters," Mr Coleman said.

Mr Coleman believes the tragedy has lead to major improvements in fire equipment, training, communications and inter-agency cooperation.

Mr Hall has urged the public to attend the service, with a special invitation to extended families, friends and colleagues of fire fighters lost in the line of duty.

For more information, contact Mr Hall on 0417 081 560.

Overview: The ambitious SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum project has a mission to "To research, record, conserve and promote the history and equipment of the South Australian Volunteer Fire Service".

A fire fighters' memorial honouring the lives of SA volunteer fire fighters was opened to the public at the completion of stage one.

Work on the Kingston Ave site is still ongoing, with an eventual museum complex that will house an extensive CFS memorabilia collection set to follow.

Mr Hall said at the end of the stage one it felt rewarding to have part of the history of fire fighting here in Naracoorte.

"It's really rewarding to think that's it's chosen as Naracoorte but it's fitting that it's part of the history of the fire service," Mr Hall said.

urn:contentItem:5MWF-43G1-JD34-V2N7-00000-00Urgent review ordered into state track-blocking policy2017-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Urgent review ordered into state track-blocking policyWilliam Vallely

AN urgent review into the state government's track-blocking policy has been ordered by the environment minister after a department deliberately tore down trees in protected crown land.

Hundreds of trees were recently destroyed in Whroo state forest by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning - a decision it says it took to prevent illegal motor cross riders using a trail in the forest.

However, Environment Minister Lily D'Ambrosio said she was not informed of the action and has asked for an urgent explanation as to why this has occurred.

"I've also directed DELWP to immediately review its policy for track blocking and closures, this simply isn't good enough," she said.

The devastation, which uprooted native Ironbark and Grey Box trees, was labelled "environmental vandalism" by state member for northern Victoria, Wendy Lovell.

"The actions of the department are environmental vandalism by the very people who have been charged with protecting the forest," Mrs Lovell said.

"Surely there could have been another approach or other methods put in place before they started to destroy the forest."

The now "dangerous" forest posed risks not only to the public, but emergency services, Mrs Lovell said.

"It (blocking the track) has restricted access to the forest for firefighting and other rescue operations that need to go on."

The Liberal MP said she will be asking Minister D'Ambrosio for a restoration of the track.

"To put up signs afterwards is not good enough," said Mrs Lovell, who suggested the local community should have been consulted by the department.

"They (DELWP) have bypassed dead trees because they consider them to be habitat for animals and knocked over completely live trees."

The member for northern Victoria said video footage of the trail showed motor cross riders could still get around the track, meaning the forest, and the riders, were at further risk.

The department said approximately 100 trees had been pushed over and the non-habitat trees used were small and no larger than 30 centimetres in diameter.

Works to rehabilitate the track are scheduled to start in the next few weeks, while temporary signs will be put up by Wednesday evening and permanent signs will go up this week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will work with the community on a long- term solution to rehabilitate the track.

Native Vegetation Clearing regulations did not apply to DELWP in this case, the department said.

urn:contentItem:5MXP-YB21-F0J6-J1DW-00000-00Feast of farming and flora2017-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNONEPg. 28Feast of farming and flora

THERE will be a feast of farming, flora and fisheries on the menu at the Agriculture Victoria tent at this year's Wimmera Machinery Field Days at Longerenong.

The marquee, which is adjacent to the field days office, also features Wimmera Catchment Management Authority and Department of Environment Land, Water and Planning.

Agriculture Victoria displays will provide plenty of information about how agricultural businesses can make the most of their cropping and livestock enterprises.

There will be department staff available to help with any livestock health and welfare issues and also talk about a range of land health workshops and activities coming up in 2017.

Grain farmers can reap plenty of important information from the site with climate, soils and nutrients and agronomy among the topics on offer. Members of the department's Horsham Cereal Pathology team will be available throughout the field days to discuss cereal disease questions.

Last year's wet spring has provided its fair share of disease challenges and staff will be on hand to both talk about these issues and also hand out the 2017 Cereal and Pulse Disease Guides and updated fact sheets.

Science is also on the agenda with the Australian Grains Genebank showcasing the Get into Grains program, which is aimed at grade 5 and 6 students, along with their amazing display of seeds from all corners of the globe.

There will be plenty of interactive games designed to be both fun and informative, helping children learn all about seeds, including why they are different from each other.

Anglers will have a chance to get a copy of the new Victorian Recreational Fishing Guide 2017, which covers current recreational fishing gear entitlements and daily catch and size limits which apply for the Wimmera.

Staff from the Department of Environment Water and Planning will also be on hand to discuss a range of issues including native vegetation and threatened species.

There will also be forest fire management representatives on hand as well.

Staff from Vicmap Topographic Maps, will again display their maps which show natural and constructed features including contours, rivers, streams, waterfalls, lakes, vegetation, roads, cliffs, localities, park boundaries and shipwrecks.

And if all of these people can't answer your questions, DEDJTR's customer service centre officers will be on site to help you find the information you need.

Wimmera Catchment Management Authority will also be in the marquee and there will be a kid's section where children can colour in, have their photo taken and participate in a quiz.

urn:contentItem:5T1W-FSC1-JD34-V0PB-00000-00The Illawarra's worst August fire weather in more than a decade2018-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisThe Illawarra's worst August fire weather in more than a decadeAndrew Pearson

Dry winds gusting up to 110km/h and unseasonably-warm winter temperatures combined to deliver the worst August fire weather in more than a decade across parts of the Illawarra and Shoalhaven on Wednesday.

Weatherzone meteorologist Graeme Brittain said the forest fire danger index (FFDI) - which takes into account temperature, wind speed and humidity - reached its highest August level in just over 15 years at Albion Park. Nowra's FFDI was the highest in 14 years.

Wind gusts of 109km/h and 104km/h were recorded at Bellambi and Nowra, respectively, on Wednesday morning.

It has been almost two years since Bellambi had a wind gust that strong.

The vigorous west to northwesterly winds came ahead of a cold front, which was due to arrive on Wednesday night.

The dangers posed by the strong winds were compounded by temperatures that climbed as high as eight degrees above average for this time of the year.

A maximum of 25.6 degrees was recorded at Bellambi, it was 24.5 in Albion Park and 23.5 at Nowra.

A fire weather warning was issued for the Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Greater Sydney and Greater Hunter fire districts late-morning.

Total fire bans were also issued in those areas - the earliest bans of the season in almost a decade, according to the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS).

The Bureau of Meteorology's NSW severe weather manager Simon Louis said the strong winds and dry conditions combined to cause very-high to severe fire danger across the Illawarra.

The lack of recent rainfall and "very dry fuels" also contributed to the severe fire danger conditions, Mr Louis said.

"We haven't had a fire weather warning for the Illawarra in August since 2009, and that again comes back to the very dry lead-in we've had to this season and the very dry state that the fuels are in," he said.

While major fires burned in the Nowra and Ulladulla areas, fallen power lines did spark a blaze off Mount Brandon Road at Jerrara, west of Kiama, just before 9am.

RFS and Fire and Rescue NSW crews worked quickly to protect properties as gusty winds fanned the flames.

RFS district officer David Hitchens described the wind as "quite severe".

"Winds that are above 100km/h ... from multiple directions [makes it] very hard to contain a fire and the crews that were here today [Wednesday] did an extremely good job to do that," Mr Hitchens said.

Meanwhile, the wild winds saw NSW State Emergency Service (SES) crews respond to about 65 jobs across the Illawarra and South Coast on Wednesday.

More than 30 of the jobs, most of which were for roof damage and fallen trees and branches, were in the Illawarra.

The remainder stretched across the Shoalhaven, as far south as Milton.

Buildings have been destroyed after two separate, out-of-control fires ripped through bush and burned quickly towards homes in the Shoalhaven on Wednesday.

Wild winds fanned fires in Bomaderry and at Mount Kingiman, west of Ulladulla, with emergency alerts issued for residents in both areas.

At Bomaderry, a bushfire burning between West Cambewarra Road and the Princes Highway flared about 11am.

The fire destroyed at least one shed in a residential backyard, as firefighters on the ground and in the sky worked to halt its spread.

The fire's alert level was downgraded mid-afternoon, but it remained uncontrolled late on Wednesday.

Down the coast, residents in the Woodstock area, west of Ulladulla, were told it was too late to leave as a fast-moving fire approached.

One shed was confirmed lost in that fire, which was downgraded to a 'watch and act' alert level on Wednesday evening.

RFS building assessment teams have been deployed to the Shoalhaven to assess the property damage associated with both fires.

How the events of Wednesday unfolded.

urn:contentItem:5FWF-FHJ1-JC0X-K08N-00000-00CIS:Chernobyl wildfire nearly extinguished2015-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSCIS:Chernobyl wildfire nearly extinguished

  UKRAINE FIRE
   KIEV, April 30 AFP - Firefighters have nearly extinguished a forest fire near Ukraine's Chernobyl plant, the scene of the world's worst nuclear accident in 1986.


   "There are no more open flames," but fires are still smouldering out of sight, said the deputy head of the emergencies ministry, Mykola Chechetkin, cited by Interfax-Ukraine news agency.
   "Until it is completely extinguished, we will carry out measures to observe and douse it. I think we will carry out these measures for another 48 hours," he said.
   A Ukrainian scientist, meanwhile, criticised the authorities for a lack of safety equipment for the firefighters including face-masks.
   "Their respiratory organs aren't protected. They are simply using spades or some kind of brushes to beat out the flames and they are breathing in that smoke," said the head of the general radiation safety department at the Institute for Nuclear Research, Sergiy Azarov.
   The blaze came within about 20km of Chernobyl after breaking out on Tuesday afternoon, but officials said it posed no danger to the plant and radiation levels in the zone remained unchanged.
   Emergency services say firefighters are now battling isolated areas of flames "within a controlled perimetre".
   The area around Chernobyl was evacuated after the 1986 blast and the last reactor there was shut down in 2000 but some personnel still operate in the exclusion zone, where work is underway to build a new seal over the reactor site.
   Officials gave few details of the possible cause of the fire but Ukraine's Interior Minister Arsen Avakov said authorities had not ruled out arson.
   The fire struck just two days after Ukrainians marked 29 years since the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.
   AFP aro

urn:contentItem:5KT4-51J1-JD34-V085-00000-00Governing like an arson squad2016-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Governing like an arson squadSKETCHSKETCH Tony Wright

When you're in a forest fire it's usually sensible not to spray lighter fuel in every direction.

The Andrews government takes a different view. Its plan appears to be to call for a convoy of methylated spirits to be trucked in and to blast a stream of the stuff on the flames at the merest sign the conflagration might die down.

How else to explain that the acting minister for emergency services, Lisa Neville, was forced yesterday to slither away, humiliated, from her own apparently greatly exaggerated rumour of the early demise of the former MFB fire chief, Peter Rau?

After months of farce concerning the United Firefighters Union, the CFA and the government's inability to put out an ember without sacking or forcing the resignation of everyone in sight - including Ms Neville's predecessor as emergency services minister, Jane Garrett - Ms Neville has now dropped a match into the Metropolitan Fire Brigade's protracted industrial bushfire.

Peter Rau, she declared publicly, had resigned because he was "gravely ill". In normal public discourse, such language is used when someone is at death's door.

Not true, fumes Mr Rau's wife, Tracey Rau. Why, she and her husband had been forced to reassure family and friends it wasn't the case at all. The main reason her husband had resigned, Mrs Rau stated, was because of stress caused by bullying dished out by the United Firefighters Union and the mess surrounding the dispute over enterprise bargaining.

Ms Neville was left falling over herself, declaring she was "absolutely genuinely sorry ... if I have caused any distress to Peter and his family". If?

But why would a minister have consigned a senior official to retirement among the ranks of the "gravely ill" in the first place?

Mrs Rau believes it was to distract attention from bullying union tactics against MFB management during the past two years of industrial disputation. That may very well be so. but it still doesn't explain how a government, from Premier Andrews down, has allowed itself to burn up months and months of political capital on the UFU, the CFA and everything associated, and has now set a new blaze flaring around the MFB for no reason at all. Arson or incompetence? Both, surely.
