urn:contentItem:5MS7-03J1-JD3N-51BF-00000-00Dry to stretch into April2017-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Dry to stretch into AprilBy JAMES WAGSTAFF and KATH SULLIVAN

A LATE autumn break is on the cards for farmers across southeast Australia, with well below-average rain forecast for the next three months.

The Bureau of Meteorology's latest climate outlook suggests parts of the Victorian Mallee and the NSW Riverina could receive just 10-25mm between now and the end of April - less than half of what they would normally expect.

Parts of the Wimmera and central Victoria could receive just 25-50mm with only slightly better - but still well below-average - conditions forecast for southwest Victoria, Gippsland and the North East.

The fairly bleak outlook has also heightened concerns that this year's fire season could continue well into autumn. The first statewide total fire ban of the summer was ordered on Monday as temperatures peaked at 41.3C at Mildura and 40.7C at Swan Hill.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's Murray Goldfields forest fire manager Paul Bates said this fire season had been "interesting", with only a handful of fire bans declared despite high fuel loads caused by record rain last year.

"It's like the fire season has been delayed," Mr Bates said. "(But) we've still got six weeks to two months of fire risk (left) in the landscape. There's still a lot of summer to go.

"What's unusual is the grass growth on the roadside and in paddocks - that says the risk is still present." Incoming Victorian Farmers Federation grains president Ross Johns, of Warracknabeal, said the drier outlook heading into autumn would not be too much of a concern to farmers "as long as it remembers to rain" after April.

The Bureau's outlook points to the likelihood of a drier-than-average three months for all of Victoria, NSW, South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland. The forecast followed a mixed month of rain for southeast Australia during January, with some centres receiving more than one-and-a-half times their monthly rain while other struggled to achieve a quarter.

The best falls, compared with the long-term average, were in western Victoria, with Ararat picking up 60.8mm for the month to 9am yesterday or 155 per cent of its 39.1mm January average.At the other end of the scale, Sale, in Gippsland, had just 11.6mm of rain for the month, or 26 per cent of its long-term average.

urn:contentItem:5PTG-WFT1-F0J6-J19W-00000-00Wood camp fires off limits in local State Forests2017-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisWood camp fires off limits in local State Forests

CAMPFIRES and barbecues using wood, charcoal or other solid fuels will be banned in most State Forests until further notice to reduce the risk of bushfires.

Forestry Corporation of NSW's senior manager of Stewardship, Kathy Lyons, said campers and picnickers could continue to bring and use gas stoves during the ban, except during declared total fire bans.

"Fire season has commenced early this year due to the very dry conditions and warmer days across much of the State. Forest fuels and soils are extremely dry and our firefighters on the North Coast are already fully committed fighting many fires which have taken off due to windy conditions.

"Recently we have had three wildfires ignite from escaped campfires - one each on the South Coast, Hunter and Mid North Coast.

FLASHBACK: State Forest fire on northern edge of Nambucca

"All fires using solid fuels such as wood or charcoal are now banned in most State Forests across the State until further notice. This ban applies to State Forests of the South Coast, Sapphire Coast, the Watagan Mountains, Barrington Tops, Mid North Coast, Coffs Coast, Northern and Southern Tablelands, Central West, Mid-West and North-West.

"Campers and picnickers wishing to light a fire to cook in these forests can only use gas appliances until the ban is lifted which won't be until after significant rainfall.

"This ban applies every day, not just on days when total fire bans are declared, so we are asking people who are planning to camp in the forests during spring and summer to plan ahead and bring gas appliances.

"Visitors should also be prepared for days when total fire bans are declared, as all fires including gas fires are prohibited on total fire ban days. Information on total fire bans is available on the Rural Fire Service website."

Ms Lyons said solid fuel fire bans had been enforced in a number of State Forests since 1990 to reduce the risk of bushfires.

"State Forests are popular with campers and visitors throughout the spring and summer period and while we encourage people to get out into our forests and enjoy them, we do need to act to reduce the bushfire risk during the high fire danger period," Ms Lyons said.

"Solid fuel fire bans improve safety for campers and local communities and they have also potentially helped save many thousands of hectares of forests from destructive fires since 1990."

The exception to this ban is State Forests in the Snowy Mountains and the River Red Gum where the forests are not as dry due to recent snow and rain.

Failure to comply with the Solid Fuel Fire Ban carries a maximum penalty of $2200.

For more information about Forestry Corporation of NSW, visit www.forestrycorporation.com.au In the event of a fire or other emergency, contact 000.

urn:contentItem:5PDG-TH71-F0JP-W060-00000-00YOUR NATION2017-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 2YOUR NATION

Nine journo gets more time on porn charges NSW: Nine Network reporter Ben McCormack has been granted more time to negotiate with prosecutors after he faced a Sydney court on two child pornography charges. The Current Affair journalist, who was suspended from the network after his April arrest, was in court yesterday as his lawyer asked a magistrate for three more weeks to complete negotiations with the prosecution. Sam Macedone said a plea "will be entered" when the matter returns to court on September 26. McCormack, 43, has been charged with two counts of using a carriage service to transmit, publish or promote child porn.

Police powers bolstered on terror QUEENSLAND: Police will now have extra powers to respond to terror threats after the state parliament passed tough new laws. Officers will be able to access and search electronic devices during a declared terror emergency, to more quickly identify people and gain access to information. The laws also strengthen surveillance powers as well as give police greater latitude to move and destroy homemade explosives. The government said safeguards had also been built into the laws to ensure a "balance" between the new powers and individuals rights and liberties. A public interest monitor will be tasked with putting together an annual report on surveillance warrants.

State warned to brace for fire threat VICTORIA: Victorians need to brace themselves for a potentially harsher and earlier fire season than normal, authorities warn. After one of Australia's warmest and driest winters on record, large parts of the eastern states and South Australia have been marked "red" in the 2017 Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook. The CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria have also brought forward prevention strategies, including burn-offs.

Anglicans strengthen rules to keep kids safe QUEENSLAND: Anglican priests across Australia will be required to follow strict new rules to protect children from abuse after legislation was passed by its governing body. Clergy and church workers will now be required to abide by a code of conduct which they had previously only needed to treat as recommendations. "It covers things like transport, no corporal punishment, issues of touch and photographs," Royal Commission Working Group chair Garth Blake said. Stricter screening of sex offenders in parishes will also apply and could even result in some being turned away. The Anglican Church of Australia unanimously voted in favour of the mandatory guidelines at its three-yearly General Synod on the Sunshine Coast yesterday.

Cop charged with uploading sex videoNSW: A NSW police officer has been charged with secretly filming himself having sex with a female colleague and uploading the footage to social media. The pair met up in Sydney's CBD in July this year while they were both off duty. The 27-year-old, a senior constable attached to a specialist command, was arrested and charged on Monday, police revealed in a statement.

urn:contentItem:5H90-6941-JD3N-51PR-00000-00World's smallest snail found2015-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 9World's smallest snail foundJohn Ross

KUALA LUMPUR: Scientists say they have found the terrestrial world's smallest snail after sieving soil samples from Borneo's northern tip.

The tiny Acmella nana, which measures about half a millimetre across, is described this morning in the journal ZooKeys. It takes the record from a 0.8mm-wide Chinese snail revealed to the world in the same journal just five weeks ago.

Reports at the time enthused that 10 of the Chinese "microsnails" could fit into the eye of a needle. About 19 of the nespecimens, named after the Latin word for dwarf, could occupy the same space.

The midget mollusc is one of 48 new species revealed today. Seven are only found on 4095m Mount Kinabalu, Malaysia's highest peak. Another lives only at the entrance to a remote cave on Gunung Trusmadi, the country's second-highest mountain. "A blazing forest fire at Loloposon Cave could wipe out the entire population," warned co-discoverer Menno Schilthuizen of the Naturalis Biodiversity Centre in Leiden, Holland.

While some of the newly named species were found only recently, many were identified from soil samples collected up to 30 years ago. They included nana, whose tiny translucent shells were found in three valleys of the Malaysian state of Sabah.

"Investigations into the Sabah snail fauna are better helped by describing the species now, rather than waiting until we have preserved animals," the team explained.

Researchers around the world are in a race against time to identify some of the world's slowest-moving creatures. "Snails easily get stuck in very small patches of habitat," the journal explained. "They (are) there long enough to evolve and adapt to the limited area, undisturbed by the rest of the world."While this inability to outrun evolution makes them "excellent examples of endemic species", it also means localised natural disasters can completely wipe them out.

urn:contentItem:5RRY-STR1-JD34-V1JH-00000-00Wedge-tailed eagle sparks fire on Panmure dairy farm2018-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Wedge-tailed eagle sparks fire on Panmure dairy farmKatrina Lovell

A wedge-tailed eagle sitting on a powerline sparked a paddock fire on a Panmure dairy farm on Monday.

Farmer Peter Moir had almost finished milking his cows about 5.45pm when he heard the wind change and popped his head outside the dairy to check it out and noticed a puff of white smoke.

With winds gusting at up to 50 km/h, he immediately called 000, cleared the cows out of the way and by then Panmure fire brigade had arrived.

By the time they'd reached the fire, which was about 800 metres from the dairy and his house, the fire had already burnt across the paddock to the dirt track.

And while the willow trees on the other side of the track were scorched by the heat, firefighters were able to stop the blaze from spreading to the next paddock or the Framlingham Forest which was about 1km away.

"It was just lucky the track had pulled it up and the Panmure tanker stopped it there."

Another six or eight tankers and bomber planes from Hamilton helped bring it under control within 45 minutes.

"It was just unusual the way it burnt because it was an easterly wind. If it had been a northerly wind it would have blown to the houses or dairy," Mr Moir said.

"It just shows how easily it can happen on a day you wouldn't expect.

"If it had been 32 degrees instead of 22 degrees they would have been at the neighbour's place to stop it before it reached the bush."

The fire brought back memories of the January 10 Framlingham Forest fire that burnt the western boundary of his property 11 years ago.

The eagle, which was found dead in the paddock, was believed to have hit the powerline and sparked the blaze.

Mr Moir said that there had been a breeding pair of wedge-tailed eagles that had lived in a big gum tree on the edge of the Framlingham Forest for more than 20 years.

And even though that tree was burnt in the fire a decade ago, the eagles could be seen every two years flying around the area with their young. "We're just hoping it's not one of the breeding pair," Mr Moir said.

Mr Moir said he was impressed with how well organised the CFA was and how quickly they contained the blaze.

Crews spent two hours mopping up after the blaze and Mr Moir spent the night regularly checking on it, including getting up at 4am.

"All farmers do, you feel a responsibility even though there's no fault or blame anywhere. Then you think sure I could have rolled over and slept til 6.30am and then got up. If I hadn't got up two hours before and it had flared up and all of a sudden my neighbour's place is on fire because I didn't check it....that's what you do."

Region 5 operations operations manager Richard Bourke said the rapid response from the brigades and planes helped contain the blaze to under five hectares.

urn:contentItem:5H5B-4T91-JD34-V0JT-00000-00Fire warnings to show who is at risk2015-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Fire warnings to show who is at riskPeter Hannam

Communities and firefighters could soon receive real-time warnings of risks from bushfires down to a matter of kilometres, according to a new model being tested this fire season.

As fire crews across south-east Australia prepare for an unusually active bushfire season amid an abnormally warm spring and an intensifying El Nino, researchers hope technological advances will soon give communities real-time information on the probability of fire threats down to a resolution of a few kilometres.

"People want to know: It's a fire danger, but a fire danger to what?" says Ross Bradstock, director of the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong, and one of the developers of the new model.

"It incorporates the probability of a fire starting and spreading, based on the fuel and the terrain, and it reaching property," Professor Bradstock said. "The warning system can be tailored to parts of towns or even suburbs."

The current warning system, modified after the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria to include a "catastrophic" threat level, has been based on the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index first developed in the 1960s. That method, however, is based only on weather, such as temperature, relative humidity and wind speed.

A prototype was tested in the Sydney region, including the Blue Mountains, and east of Melbourne. The model will be tested in NSW this year.

"You can have a region with a lower fire rating but have a particular location with a higher risk," said Trent Penman, a bushfire behaviour specialist at the University of Melbourne, and another developer of the new model. "For people in those properties to know they are at higher risk would be beneficial for their preparations."

Victoria and NSW are divided into large fire districts. The new model potentially could provide "fine grained" warnings of potential property loss down to five kilometres or less.

urn:contentItem:5KTB-9B51-F0J6-J4PY-00000-00Fire safety threat2016-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisFire safety threatSophie Boyd

THE Wimmera could face another severe bushfire season this summer, despite a wet winter.

The Bureau of Meteorology has released its south Australian seasonal bushfire outlook, which showed western Victoria had the highest bushfire risk in the state.

The report said wet weather had resulted in extensive grass growth across the region. Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said he predicted high summer temperatures and excess vegetation had increased the risk of grass fire.

Country Fire Authority District 16 operations manager Chris Eagle said the outlook for the region was in line with previous years, depending on rainfall.

"In summer there will always be fires. It's just a matter of how big and what you can do about them," he said.

"We aren't predicting any significant rainfall in summer so we are working on the premise that the wet winter has promoted grass growth and created fuel.

"It all depends on how much rain we get in spring, and how hot and dry it is over summer - whether the grass dried out completely or the rain keeps it green."

Mr Eagle said the fire season would be start as usual in mid to late November.

He said the increased rainfall also had other implications.

"We've noticed the dams are starting to fill up, which hasn't happened in recent years," he said. "It means bonus water sources for us.

"Getting more rain keeps the forests damper over summer, which decreases the chance of a forest fire."

District 17 acting operations manager Trevor Ebbels said residents were 100 per cent responsible for preparing their land for summer.

"It's a strong message but it's the responsibility of a property owner to keep an eye on things and get work done in preparation," he said.

"One of the hardest things about this amount of rain is people can do the work, do slashing and it keeps growing back.

"My advice for land owners is to ensure they do the work - do it in time and don't wait for fire restrictions."

Mr Ebbels said the authority fire safety was important heading into fire season, but just as vital while the temperature was lower. "We're in a state of readiness all year round," he said.

"The authority is 365 days a year, seven days and 24 hours a day."

He said fire season preparations had started.

urn:contentItem:5VJR-N8M1-JD3N-512X-00000-00Crown land growth 'fuelled fire'2019-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 3Crown land growth 'fuelled fire'RACHEL BAXENDALE, CHIP LE GRAND, Additional reporting: Tessa Akerman

Residents of a small rural community heaviest hit by Victoria's weekend bushfires believe dan-g-er-ously high fuel loads on vacant- crown land contributed to the feroci-ty of a blaze that left Country Fire Authority firefighters unable to defend some properties.

The quiet hamlet of Tonimbuk, about 90km east of Melbourne, felt the brunt of the fire crisis, with seven properties destroyed and 11,000ha burnt by a lightning-strike blaze that raced out of the Bunyip State Forest.

Andrew Clarke, the owner of the Jinks Creek Winery destroyed by the Bunyip fire, believes a bureaucrati-c blunder cost him his life's work.

He said a planned burn-off in 60ha between his vineyard and the state park was not done because of concerns for local birdlife.

"If they'd been doing the burning off they should have been doing, our place might still be there," he told The Australian.

"They told me birds were nesting. I told them: 'If we don't do a burn-off now, there'll be no birds. There'll be no goannas, no snakes, no wallabies. They'll all be bar-becued." Another Tonimbuk resident, cartoonist Mark Knight, said some residents were left to defend their homes without assistance from the CFA. "We fought this fire for three days on our own," he said. "Black Saturday they were all over us. They were fantastic. We didn't see them this year." A spokesman for the CFA said: "There are more than 2000 emergency services personnel currently working on multiple fires across the state. We can't have a firetruck on everyone's doorstep and we prioritise accordingly." Rex Newton, 70, returned to his Tonimbuk home and wildlife refuge- yesterday to find it burnt to the ground. He said he was near the rear of his property when he saw fire race over a hill towards his back door. "I only have the clothes on my back and it isn't that nice a shirt," he told the ABC as he sifted through ash and twisted metal. By the time he managed to load his dog, cat and cockatoo and jump into a car, the fire had singed the hair on his arms.

Firefighting resources have been stretched to breaking point, with crews tackling almost 20 significant- fires across the state. Although the crisis had abated last night, emergency services were bracing for the impact of a viole-nt weather change expected to bring strong winds, lightning strikes and possibly snow to some of the same alpine areas scorched by fire.

A Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman, when asked why fuel reduction burning had not been carried out on the crown land next to the Bunyip State Park, said that under a change to fire risk management, burning had become- more targeted.

"We are using a risk-reduction target to focus our fuel-management strategies on areas that will have the greatest impact," the spokesman said. "This target means we are burning smarter, rather than focusing on a number-of-hectares target.

"In some cases this may mean less planned burns - in other areas it may mean more - but communities can be assured that our activities are focused on making them safer and protecting their local environment." The immediate threat shifted yesterday from Tonimbuk to the alpine town of Dargo, where the small community was at one point menaced by two bushfires.

Leanne Estcourt said from insid-e the historic Dargo Hotel that the town was encircled by smoke, with the skies glowing lumin-ous orange. Some town residents sought shelter in the pub.

"We have got some people that are here that the fires are affecting their properties as we speak," Ms Estcourt said. "It is pretty stressful when you don't know the situation and how bad it is." By late afternoon, the threat to properties in Dargo had eased, althoug-h the fires were not under control.

The Tonimbuk fire was the worst to hit the area since Black Saturday 10 years ago, when a fire which began in the Bunyip State Park destroyed 31 houses and burnt more than 26,000ha.Graeme Moore, the Mayor of Cardinia Shire, which takes in Tonimbuk, said his community had been hammered by the fire but praised the CFA.

urn:contentItem:5XVW-B8W1-JD34-V0YN-00000-00Fiery end to the decade2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Fiery end to the decadeLaura Chung, Jenny Noyes and Matt Bungard

Thousands of holidaymakers between Ulladulla and Culburra Beach including Jervis Bay on the NSW South Coast have been warned that the escalating bushfires threaten to trap them.

With temperatures set to climb past 40 degrees in western Sydney and parts of regional NSW today, the Princes Highway may be closed and the Kings Highway was already shut down, fire authorities said.

A Rural Fire Service volunteer firefighter was killed last night, and two others suffered burns while battling the Green Valley fire 70 kilometres east of Albury.

It is believed that their truck rolled after being hit by extreme winds while battling the fire, one of four emergency blazes burning around the state as of 7pm.

In Victoria, nine separate emergency warnings were in force and fires threatened homes on the suburban fringes of Melbourne.

On the NSW South Coast, three blazes - the Currowan, Charleys Forest and Clyde Mountain fires - have joined, forming a large fire that has burnt through more than 257,000 hectares, stretching from near Batemans Bay to near Nowra.

There are also fears the Green Wattle Creek fire south-west of Sydney could jump containment lines near Colo Vale.

A southerly change with winds up to 35km/h is expected to move up the coast this morning and will make conditions more challenging for firefighters, with the buster set to hit Sydney in the late afternoon. There are fears possible thunderstorms coupled with dry lightning strikes could ignite new blazes.

There are total fire bans in effect for 11 areas, including those facing "extreme" and "severe" fire danger.

Shoalhaven Council alderman and volunteer firefighter Mitchell Pakes said fire conditions would worsen today and tomorrow with rising temperatures and dry winds.

"If you can delay travel plans, it's a good idea to do that," Mr Pakes said.

"A lot of coastal villages have one road in and out. My advice for holidaymakers on the coast is that it's too late to leave now, particularly with the weather worsening tonight and into tomorrow."

This warning also covers towns including Mollymook, Lake Conjola and Huskisson.

"The reality is if you are in a small coastal village, it's safer for you to stay there," he said.

Mr Pakes said the warning was not a "knee-jerk reaction" and was instead well calculated.

Just across the border, the Victorian coastal town of Mallacoota was awaiting the flames last night. An emergency community meeting was held in the town, which is surrounded by the wilderness of the Croajingolong National Park, early yesterday and only hours after more than 100 firefighters arrived overnight.

"The concern is a big fire could be coming, but it will be coming in the middle of the night," Darryl Burns, ranger in charge of fire and emergency operations in East Gippsland, said at the meeting. "That wind change will drive the fire towards us. It will be a long day and a long night."

Mallacoota resident Michelle Roberts, who owns the Croajingolong Cafe overlooking the inlet, was closing up just after 2pm and planning to evacuate her house.

"We're all very nervous here," she said. "There are a lot of tourists around, getting coffees and wanting to be fed, I don't think they are taking it as seriously as the locals."

Ms Roberts was going home to quickly pack some of her belongings before returning to her cafe and taking shelter there overnight.

"There is no real safe place so a lot of people are being told to come down and wait near the wharf which is where my cafe is so I will just wait it out here," she said.

NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Greg Allen said, "Our advice is certainly not to be in bushland areas if you don't have to be and, if that means delaying travel until these conditions are more benign, that would be our advice.

"The last thing we want to see is people stuck on any road away from their home and property, so please delay travel if you can and stay away from bushland areas."

Mr Allen said major road closures were possible and would be determined by fire conditions.

Sydney residents Liz and Tony Whittingham arrived in Lake Conjola on Friday and are booked to stay until January 2, but because of changing fire conditions the couple have not unpacked and are considering cutting short their holiday.

"It's a bit of a different holiday, rather than just mooching around, you've got one eye on the weather two or three times a day," Mrs Whittingham said.

They were likely to stay unless the weather conditions deteriorated further. "We have to ride with it," she said.

Illawarra resident Michael Webb is holidaying in Mossy Point, 16 kilometres from Batemans Bay, and said ash was raining down on his car.

"It's been a bit spooky - the sun is very red," he said. "We are now surrounded by fire on three sides so the sea will be the only route of escape."

He said the bushfires had not disrupted his holiday and he was unlikely to cut it short, but said the smoke levels and visibility had been particularly bad yesterday.

At 3pm, 100 fires were burning around the state, 50 of which were yet to be contained.

The four fires at "emergency warning" level last night were the Dunns Road fire near Wagga Wagga, the Green Valley fire in Greater Hume, Myrtle Mountain Road near Bega, and the Charleys Forest fire near Queanbeyan. Four other fires along the South Coast were at "watch and act".

The Southern Ranges, Illawarra and Shoalhaven areas face "extreme" fire danger ratings today, while areas including Greater Sydney, Greater Hunter, central ranges and the Far South Coast have been issued "severe" fire danger ratings.

The Rural Fire Service said yesterday 911 homes had been destroyed in NSW to date in this bushfire season, along with 72 facilities and more than 2000 outbuildings.

with Melissa Cunningham

urn:contentItem:59MH-2TJ1-JD34-V0HS-00000-00Hot and dry conditions align for fiery season2013-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Hot and dry conditions align for fiery seasonNSW BUSHFIRESÂ»NATASHA WALLACE, PETER HANNAM

A ''long, hot winter'' and recent drought conditions that are consistent with the effects of climate change have created the extreme bushfire conditions already experienced this season, according to a leading bushfire expert.

The conditions needed for bushfires - a continuous layer of dry vegetation coupled with hot, windy weather - are increasingly occurring in the Australian landscape, Professor Ross Bradstock, from the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong, said.

''We had an unusually warm, dry winter and early spring, and now we don't know definitively if that is definitely due to climate change or not but it's certainly indicative of what we think will happen in the future,'' he said.

With the state remaining on high alert as the weather heats up again from Sunday, the CSIRO'S Justin Leonard said it was an abnormal start to the season.

''These sort of losses so early in the season don't fit the normal profile, they definitely stand out as quite an early season loss,'' Mr Leonard said. ''You could assume that as the frequency [of high-risk fire weather days] increases you might get a longer fire season.''

Scientists have warned of more days of extreme fire danger due to climate change for decades.

Changes in the Forest Fire Danger Index have already shown that many regions have had an increase in extreme fire weather, partly due to the increasing intensity and duration of hot days - January this year was the hottest month on record.

The index increased significantly at 16 of 38 weather stations across Australia between 1973 and 2010, producing a longer fire season.

A 2006 CSIRO report updated this year stated the combined frequencies of days with very high and extreme fire danger ratings are likely to increase by 4 per cent to 25 per cent by 2020 and 15 per cent to 70 per cent by 2050.

However, Professor Bradstock said the present fires were not particularly unusual in the context of the past 50 years.

''They are within what we could call the historical range of variation. They are not outside the envelope. We haven't seen anything that breaks records,'' he said. ''[But] it's getting warmer and drier, and we may see more of the extreme fire days if the climate change predictions come to fruition.''

The director of ARC Centre of Excellence for Climate System Science, Andy Pitman, said global warming meant warmer winters, which would create vegetation conditions suitable for fires.

''It's perfectly plausible'' there could be a week of days with 35-degree maximum heat and 50km/h winds in the future, he said.

''We are clearly and demonstrably vulnerable [to fires] and all of the trends point to that vulnerability being amplified in the future,'' Professor Pitman said.

Public concern tended to be temporary, he said, with complacency setting in quickly. ''Even the Black Saturday fires [in Victoria] really don't change people's behaviour for more than a year or two.''

Six months ago, the former Climate Commission released its Critical Decade report warning extreme fire weather days had been on the rise for 30 years in many parts of Australia, including southern NSW.

''The projections for the future indicate a significant increase in dangerous fire weather for south-east Australia,'' it said.

urn:contentItem:5MH6-HJX1-JD34-V2BM-00000-00'Bush doof' shut down2016-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:19ZLexisNexis'Bush doof' shut downShana Morgan

Most people would not have heard about the rave planned for about 500 people in the Buckland Valley forest earlier this month, but rangers certainly did.

They got word about the event early and arrived at the destination just as the organiser and two others were setting up portable toilets and other equipment.

Having no permit meant the rave was shut down by police and Forest Fire Management Victoria before it started.

FFMV senior forest investigator Samantha Moore said 500 people had had committed to going and 1500 said they were "interested" in the event on Facebook.

"First and foremost, it's about safety â€¦ consideration is not given to important controls such as first aid requirements, dangerous trees, toilet and litter facilities, accessibility for emergency services in the event of an incident or bushfire, or the impact that the events have on the environment," she said.

"They are for-profit parties, they're making money from it."

Authorised festivals are required to meet guidelines for requirements such as medical backup, toilets and crowd control.

In this case, the Buckland Valley rave organiser warned a nearby camper he might want to move because a party was going to start.

"The forest is there for everybody to use," Ms Moore said. "It has been a significant problem in the past, not just in Buckland Valley, but around Victoria."

DELWP used its own Facebook page to contact the Buckland Valley event organiser and it was able to be cancelled before revellers took over the forest.

Ms Moore said it was usually a combination of organisers not having knowledge of the required permits and believing they could get away with it which led to trouble.

DELWP has warned any illegal raves planned in the bush for New Year parties would not be tolerated.

Charges for conducting an activity for profit on Crown land can be heard in court and be dealt with by fines between $3109 for an individual and $15,546 for a company.

The worst-case scenario for an unauthorised rave occurred near Grafton in June when a 24-year-old man died in his car, 200 metres from where people were dancing.

NSW Police Detective Inspector Darren Jameson said rave organisers showed no regard for safety.

"They need to be shut down and stopped - evidence of their disregard shows how they failed to stop the event despite someone dying in front of them," he said.
